docs.lead_paragraph: New research suggests that in mice, a simple treatment that does not involve drugs appears to be directing cells to turn into bone instead of fat.

headline.main: Low Buzz May Give Mice Better Bones and Less Fat
headline.print_headline: Low Buzz May Give Mice Better Bones and Less Fat

docs.snippet: New research suggests that in mice, a simple treatment that does not involve drugs appears to be directing cells to turn into bone instead of fat.

docs.lead_paragraph: Old-fashioned hygiene is advised in the war on drug-resistant staph.

headline.main: Germ Fighters May Lead to Hardier Germs
headline.print_headline: Germ Fighters May Lead to Hardier Germs

docs.snippet: Old-fashioned hygiene is advised in the war on drug-resistant staph.

docs.lead_paragraph: Reports of schoolchildren dying from infections with drug-resistant bacteria are enough to send parents on an antimicrobial cleaning frenzy. But before you start waging your own personal war on single-celled organisms, be warned. Many household and personal cleaners contain ingredients that could make the resistance problem worse.

headline.main: Germ Fighters May Lead to Hardier Germs

docs.abstract: Tara Parker-Pope Well column on recent studies that suggest that antibacterial products containing triclosan may inhibit growth of bacteria in way that leaves larger proportion of resistant bacteria behind; says general advice for avoiding infection is basic hygiene--washing hands or using alcohol-based sanitizers, keeping scrapes covered until healed and refraining from sharing personal items; photos (M)
